title: When does “The Princess Bride” take place? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well considering it’s in a fictional country, Florin, part of a fictionalised European continent, and has a fascinating but completely fantastical set-up of countries and fashions, it doesn’t have an actual time period. However, that doesn’t really answer the question, so let’s look at the evidence, and climb the Cliffs of Insanity together: Vizzini tells us he’s Sicilian, Inigo Montoya is Spanish, and Fezzik is Turkish but was “unemployed in Greenland” when Vizzini found him. Erik the Red found Greenland in about 982 (Erik the Red - the discovery of Greenland), so we’re looking at some time after that. However, it’s not likely that Fezzik got there that early. There was enough trade for Vizzini to get there and back, so he was possibly part of the expeditions from Portugal to Greenland in 1500 (Greenland) or part of the trading that occurred with Labrador after then. Inigo is fighting with a rapier not a broadsword, so it’s probably after 1500. He’s been fighting with it for more than 20 years, looking for the Six-Fingered-Man, who murdered Inigo’s father. Inigo’s father was an expert sword-maker, so the weapon had probably been around long enough for him to build a reputation, so I would put the events no earlier than 1530. Humperdinck is Prince of Florin and is attempting to frame Guilder. He’s also still living in an actual castle with soldiers, portcullis, and torches, but there’s no gunpowder, so while I would say pre-1300 if it was being used defensively, there’s no evidence he’s using the castle as anything other than a rather gorgeous house. This is Humperdinck in his castle, wearing his rather gorgeous blue outfit:  (Photo from IMDb) Which clearly has features in common with Bronzino’s painting of a young nobleman:  (Wikimedia commons) That puts Humperdinck at around 1550–1555. Of course, he could also be behind or ahead of the fashion trend, but it’s not a bad period for the Princess Bride to be set in. Another Bronzino:  (Wikimedia again) Which could be inspiration for Buttercup’s red dress. Florin is clearly a replacement for Florence, one of the fractious states of Italy, while Guilder is probably the Netherlands. Cosimo I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany was in charge at that point, and may be some inspiration for the character of Humperdinck. So, if you want to take the fashion, architecture, geographical trade routes, and sword-culture as a starting point, the late Renaissance seems about right, and at a guess between 1530 and 1560. Edit to add: With huge thanks to Nathan Sinclair who pointed out that Vizzini uses iocaine from Australia and “Unfortunately, Australia was not “entirely peopled with criminals” until after the British First Fleet arrived in 1788.” So we’re left with three possibilities: The period is in the deep future, after the fall of modernity.It is in fact as timeless as Westley’s Dread Pirate Roberts moniker.Or my favourite, in trusting Vizzini’s word about both Greenland and Australia, I “fell victim to one of the classic blunders - the most famous of which is "never get involved in a land war in Asia" - but only slightly less well-known is this: "Never go in against a Sicilian when death is on the line"!”

upvoters.user_id: Justin Mishina 三品 亮司

response.answer_text: Well its fictional but we do have some clues from the movie. One of the things i love about the movie is that during the epic duel between Wesley and Inigo Montoya they reference certain fencing masters and the styles they had. Many are not aware of the fact that the names they used were actual famous historical fencing masters. Now the styles they were referencing were not even close but it was a nice touch to include the names. Camillo Agrippa fencing treatise published in 1553. Rocco Bonetti killed in a duel 1587. Capo ferro fencing treatise published in 1610. Gérard Thibault d'Anvers fencing treatise published in 1630 (3 years after his death in 1627).
